segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Raise of hands, how many people here have used Bloodhound? Okay, good. I expect that. How many
people have used Ghostwriter? Okay, nice. How many people have used Nemesis? Okay. And how many
people have used Mythic or heard of Mythic? Okay, well, nice. Okay. So those are kind of the broad
topics that I'm going to be covering today. So it's kind of nice to see who has familiarity with
what. So I'm Cody Thomas. If you do the Twitter game, I'm at It's a Feature. I typically do a
lot of macOS research, red teaming, teaching, stuff like that. But I'm also a software engineer
here at SpectreOps, where I spend most of my time nowadays working on Mythic and red team agents to
go along with it. So today we're going to be talking about the Mythic C2 framework, the kind
of normal operational flow you expect as you operate on an engagement. And then we'll talk
about what are some unconventional aspects you might encounter. We'll just discover and talk
about the Arachne agent for web shells. And then there's a new feature in Mythic that's coming out
for third-party service agents. And so that's where we'll incorporate and talk about things
with Ghostwriter, Bloodhound, and Nemesis. So first off, what is Mythic? Why am I even talking about
it? Why do I make this? Why do we care? So Mythic is an open-source C2 framework. The link is there.
Pull requests are always welcome. It uses a microservice architecture with Docker. So the
whole point here is that you as an agent developer can focus on what you care about most, agent
development, and just plug in your agent and Mythic takes care of everything else. It handles back-end,
user authentication, UI, scripting, like all of that handled abstracted away from you. You can
just worry about that one piece. So as part of that, if you actually install Mythic, there's no
actual agents or C2 profiles you get. It's all plug-and-play and helped out a lot by the community.
So I'll show here in a couple slides some of the agents that people have contributed. With this,
there is a collaborative web UI that you connect up with. Everybody has their own login information
with access control. So you can have lead operators, normal operators, spectators, all sorts of stuff.
There's a Postgres database that saves everything for you in the back-end. And the UI and scripting
both use GraphQL as a kind of API access point. So just a kind of introductory shot here of the
main homepage dashboard for Mythic gives you a high-level overview of kind of the stuff that
you'd want to see as you come into an operation on a morning. How many callbacks do you have? How
many have called back in the last hour or so? What kinds of commands are people running? Which
ones are failing? What kinds of things do you need to troubleshoot? All sorts of stuff like that. So
with this and Mythic being a kind of community event, there's a whole bunch of agents that people
contribute. So this is a public website modeled after Cobalt Strikes Community Kit where you can
see everything that people are contributing to Mythic in the community along with how recently
they've done these commits. So you can see like Freya and Thanatos, Athena, Hermes, like all
these are agents that we at Specter Ops have not created. These are just community things that
people update and add into it for us. With this, you may be wondering, okay, that's fantastic. I
see these five agents have updated in the last month. What do they do? Or how do I know which
agents or C2 profiles I should actually install to accomplish my objective for a macOS engagement
or a certain Windows engagement? Well, up here at the top, there's that capability matrix. If you
click that, it gives you a handy breakdown of what specific capabilities each agent provides. So you
have a clear way to compare and contrast across all of them for whatever it is that you're trying
to leverage. Now Mythic overall has a what looks like a complex flow diagram. But again, these are
all just the components that come together that provide that robust UI for you. So everything is
hidden behind a reverse NGINX proxy. So you just have one interface that you connect up to and you
get proxied back to the web UI, that GraphQL scripting aspect. The back end for Mythic is in
Golang. So it has a Golang web server using GIN that goes through and handles kind of the authentication
and brains of agent processing. There's a Jupyter notebook in here that has a whole bunch of
scripting examples already set up for you. In addition to all the agents come with their own
internal documentation. Trying to have a community with all their own disparate commands and stuff
like that. That gets a little troublesome to include in the main UI. So there's an included
separate web server just for documentation on all the agents. That's here. We have the Postgres
database and RabbitMQ that goes through to allow all these various containers to connect and talk
to each other. And then of course that's just Mythic core. The things that people are contributing
are payloads, C2 profiles, different containers to handle how logging happens, and different
containers to handle how web hooks happen. So lots of different stuff. Today, though, we're going to be
just talking about this little corner here. Just these payload containers. So again, why does Mythic
matter? Why are we talking about all of this? So with this, as an agent developer, you get full
control over how tasking works, how building payloads works, those environments. You can process the
responses that come back from your agent however you want. You can manipulate the data that comes
back to display things like tables, buttons, further on tasking, all sorts of stuff instead of just
strings that you get back from like a DIR listing. You also can adjust and do whatever kind of message
format you want. Mythic uses JSON. Maybe you hate JSON and prefer some binary serialized format or
something else. Fine. You can use that in your agent and go about your day not having to worry
about it. So if we look at the normal operational flow, there's a couple of different steps. So you
set out to do a red team. All right. First thing you do is you need to pick a C2 framework. In this
case, let's say you picked Mythic. You install the C2 framework. You install whatever agents you're
going to use. You generate your payloads and you detonate them on target. Now there's two kind of
patterns that you could take here. The first one being a like beacon or polling mechanism where
your agent is reaching back periodically. So your agent phones home. You get a new connection. All
right. I have a new callback. You issue a task. The agent phones home again. Picks it up. Sometime
later, the agent phones home again. Sends the response. That's kind of your standard operational
flow. There's another kind of way you can do this that's a little less common, but still useful, as
a push style. So instead of having the agent beacon back periodically asking for tasks and stuff like
this, it can instead hold open a connection and then Mythic or your C2 platform can just push
data to it as it becomes available. This reduces a lot of the overhead of having to ask for the
same thing over and over and over again. Lots of times if you have an agent that has maybe a sleep
of one or two seconds, most of those requests that it's doing is the same generic blank response back.
Nothing submitted, nothing submitted, nothing submitted. So if you can reduce that and just
have a held open connection, you can do things this way. You get your one phone home, connection
set up, you type a task, get sent down. So the way this looks in Mythic is you as your operator over
here issue some sort of task. It goes to Mythic. Mythic validates with its role-based access
control. Are you allowed to submit this task? Is this something that you can do? It will then create
the task in the database and forward that along to your container. At this point, you as the agent
developer have full control. You've identified what parameters you want. You've identified how
processing happens. You identified what kind of scripting. If you want to hit Mythic's RPC interfaces
and create new entries and build new things and do whatever you want. All this is available for you
here. There's also two pieces in here for an OPSEC pre-flight and post-flight check. So say, for
example, as part of your tasking you want to send down a file to your agent. And maybe you're building
that dynamically. As part of these pre- and post-flight checks, you can say, okay, you've generated a file.
But before we actually let the agent pick that up and do something with it, let's make sure that we
don't have bad strings in there. Or if we did this as open source code, let's make sure we pulled out
people's handles, stuff like that. You can do these sorts of checks dynamically. So as part of this,
you're going through and you're controlling how tasking happens and all the various pieces here.
Maybe you send back strings. But ideally, it would be nice if you could send back structured data. So
if you could send back for a file listing, not just the plain text dir output that Microsoft returns,
but actually JSON data or something that's a bit more meaningful. That's great and all. Looks
something like this. But you as an operator would probably hate this. This is a lot harder for you
to kind of grok and parse through. A simple dir listing is better. But the nice thing about the
way Mythic allows you to process things is you can add browser scripts, which allows you to say,
at the UI level, getting data back like this. Let's instead do something more meaningful with it.
Let's turn it into a table, for example. So we can take this and say, okay, we got back easily processed
structured data. Now let's turn it into a clickable table with filters and searches and sorts and all
sorts of stuff that's more meaningful for an operator. So this is what I'm coming from as
the standard operational flow that you would use. Okay, lots of these different components. So if
that's standard, what is non-standard? What is unconventional? Well, let's take a different kind
of agent. Let's look at a web shell. So web shell, very common in pen testing and red teaming. You go
through typically some sort of upload or process injection. You get your malicious website code
hosted on the server. You can then do gets and posts to that web page to typically execute things.
So that's what we have here as a little example. It is a web page that just expects a CMD, a command
parameter. If it sees it, it goes through and executes it on the system and gives the data back.
Pretty straightforward, right? However, this isn't that conducive to you operating from a C2 platform,
right? If you have a web shell like this, you typically have to start doing curls or open up
in your browser and start interacting with it outside of whatever C2 platform you're using.
So the reason you have to do that is web shells don't phone home. Like either of those two
instances that we're talking about before, beaconing or one held open connection, requires an agent to
phone home. That doesn't happen with a web shell. It's just sitting there listening for you. If you
can't even get an agent to phone home and get a callback, how are you going to task it? Because
there's nothing there for you to task. As part of this, what if that web shell that you're trying
to access isn't internet accessible? What if you have to access it through an agent into an internal
network? Well, that adds even more complications to all this. So let's see if we can find a way
to make this a bit easier. So as part of this, I think last month I released an agent called Arachne.
Arachne is a web shell agent for Mythic. It has two languages, ASPX and PHP. So you can do this
on Windows or Linux. And of course, you can add in other languages and stuff as you want. It supports
full AES-256 HMAC encryption. So you don't have to worry about things going across in plain text.
And by default, it has a variety of commands, upload, download, LS, execute, stuff like that. If you are
using the ASPX Windows version, you can actually do execute assembly and upload full assemblies
and execute them there. So lots of features. But we still have some problems that we need to
overcome to allow us to use this in a C2 platform. So problem number one, there's no callback, right?
Your agent isn't phoning home. So how are you getting a callback in the first place to even
task it? So what we can do in Mythic is we can kind of precede a fake callback that eventually
will resolve to some web shell that you have listening somewhere. So what we can do, either as
part of the build process, there is an RPC endpoint that you can hit that says, hey, when you try and
build an Arachne payload, just generate a fake callback. All the data will be blank, like your
user, your IP, stuff like that, because you don't know yet. But you can at least then have something
in the UI that you task. If you don't want to do that, for any payload that you've created, you can
also come down here to this little generate callback and supply any of the data that you want,
IP, host, user, anything that's meaningful to you, and generate a callback that way. So what this
looks like in the UI looks just like any other normal callback. The last check-in time, of course,
will just be whenever it was created. There's nothing phoning home. So there is no last check-in
time. But now you have a callback. That was the first problem in general. You have something now
that you can task. And because we created this off of a payload, that payload has encryption
keys and everything set. So we have all the encryption and callback information necessary
to now start tasking it. So that next piece, how are we issuing a task? If we submit something
normally, there's no agent phoning home to then pick it up and execute it on our behalf. So what we have
to do is, from our payload container, actually make the web request ourselves. But we can do that because
as part of the container, we have full execution control of how we want our agent to work. So what
we can do here, little example on the side, where we just take a couple of steps. We take the message
that we want to send to the agent. It expects it encrypted. So this first thing that we do up here
is we just say, hey, here's a message. Mythic, please encrypt this for us. It goes through, does the AS-256
HMAC encryption for you? Fantastic. Now we just do our standard HTTP web request to our web shell
that's living. We get back an encrypted response. So ask Mythic, hey, here's this encrypted blob.
Please decrypt this for me. And now let's do something with the data. In this case, this is a
check-in message. So we created that fake callback with no meaningful data. We issue a check-in that
says kind of like a Cobalt Strike DNS C2. It has no data. You say check-in. And it gives you back
the proper PID host IP, all that sort of stuff. So that's what we're doing down here. The Arachne
agent, instead of using JSON, does pipe-delimited fields. So we just take that, split on pipes, and
update via Mythic RPC to say, hey, you know what? I had this. I issued check-in. I got these fields
back. Here's my OS, my IP user. This was a Kali box in this case. And we automatically update the
actual callback up here. So now we have full execution and tasking on this agent that doesn't
phone home to us. Now, the last thing was, what if this agent isn't publicly accessible? What if you
compromise this on an internal website that you then want to leverage and start doing things that
way? Well, there's two things then that we need to kind of handle in this case. If an internal agent
is going to connect up and issue tasks for us, there needs to be a peer-to-peer profile, a way
for that agent to know how to talk to another agent. On top of that, if we're doing things now
having Mythic pick up the task for us instead of our container just making the web shell, then we
have to have some way to convert between Mythic's JSON and just this pipe-delimited stuff that we're
trying to send to the agent. So what we can do is we can create a peer-to-peer profile in Mythic.
This is just another container that you connect up. We identify what information would be useful
for that peer-to-peer connection. So what is the cookie information that I'm sending? What's the
user agent that's needed? Are there any query parameters? The sort of stuff that you'd normally
be sending as part of your web shell. We then take that and we say, all right, now I want to
have my agent, in this case Poseidon, I want to link to that web shell. Normally for a peer-to-peer
when you try and link, you're like holding open a connection or talking over SMB, stuff like that.
This is of course still just a web shell. So all you're really doing is saying, hey, Poseidon agent
or hey, other agent, here is how you will make this specific kind of web request to this internal
compromised website that we're using. Then at this point, now you have your peer-to-peer graph.
So you have a web shell agent that's linked over a web shell peer-to-peer profile to some other
agent. At that point, all we need to do is simply convert between JSON and our piped eliminated data.
This is super, super easy. Mythic calls this translation containers. You don't have to worry
about any of that. All we're doing up here is we say, all right, I'm trying to go from JSON to
piped eliminated. So let's just remove all the JSON components and just send the actual message.
Same thing on the reverse back down here. Let's say I have all this piped eliminated data. Let me
split on those pipes and now convert it back into JSON that Mythic uses. So all of that, we're now
able to create callbacks without needing an agent to phone home to us at all. We can take these
callbacks and issue tasks with completely custom logic. Like we're bypassing a lot of the stuff
that Mythic normally does and just saying, here, reach out to this web shell and send data and then
decrypt it. And as part of this, if you're issuing these tasks through Mythic, now this kind of
solo experience of giving tasks to a web shell is now something that you can do collaboratively.
You and your other teammates can see what requests are being sent, the responses are being captured.
All this makes it a bit easier to do deconfliction and collaborate on what you're doing.
So with this, there's kind of a next logical step. Like why stop at web shell agents? Well, there are
a lot of other things that work similarly. So let's start talking about that. So Mythic is including
now this kind of third-party service agent. So if you start looking beyond operating of just what
kinds of agents are you doing, what other things are you doing in general as you operate? You typically
are tracking your logs, objectives that you're doing, your findings or what artifacts are you
dropping to disk, all these sorts of things you're having to maintain somewhere. Here at SpecDrops, we
add in a lot of this into Ghostwriter. You may have additional tooling that you're using, like
Bloodhound or Nemesis to aggregate this data and get more insight into what's happening.
You'll probably have something for team collaboration, Slack, Mattermost, RocketChat,
like whatever it is that you're using. You might have to be writing your report in line as you're
operating. So being able to speed up that process is really helpful. And you might have additional
infrastructure management. Like partway through an assessment, you may find that your domain is
burned and you need to stand up more redirectors or change configurations. Like all these sorts of
things you're having to do on a daily basis that take you outside of your normal C2 platforms.
You're having to hop between tabs or different programs all together. The problem with this
is you end up with a lot of duplicated entry. You're having to copy and paste things or you're
manually typing things in from one platform to another. That's error-prone. It's tedious. It gives
context switching overhead and tiredness to operators that makes them more error-prone.
There has to be a way that we can make this a bit easier. So what Mythic has decided is that since
we already saw how you can interact with a web shell. A web shell is just a different service
that's listening for web requests. Well, it's no different than interacting with an API for some
other program. Well, why don't we take the same sort of stuff that we did for Arachne and apply
it to these other things that we're leveraging? So the main difference here is that with Arachne
and with web shells, you're authenticating. But it's really just like your C2 server authenticating.
Ideally for these third-party platforms, we want to be able to authenticate as myself. Not as Mythic
or this specific Mythic deployment, but I want my access to be different than my teammates' access
to our shared reporting platform, for example. So we want to be able to have a way to capture that
nuance, but still have a way that you can issue tasks right in line as you go about, you know,
actually controlling agents. So is there a way we can go about doing this? Well, that first thing
that we need to tackle is how we're going to differentiate myself from my partner in terms of
these third-party services. So we don't want to have you create API tokens for these services and
drop them on disk. We don't want to have to have them in like env configs that anybody can read
on target. We want this to be a little bit more protected and a little bit more user-specific.
If you add a new user to an operation, we want them to be able to hop in and use these services
as well. So what Mythic does is if you go to your user settings, there is now this little key icon.
You can click this and view just your user-specific keys. So these are your secrets that you're
configuring, your key value pairs, just kind of like secrets that you'd have for, you know, GitHub
Actions or stuff like that, any sort of CICD stuff. And these secrets then get sent down as part of
your tasking for issuing tasks to your agent. That means that now as part of that control flow
where you are making your web requests, you have access to the user-specific data. Fantastic.
So let's figure out how we can leverage this to make our lives a little bit easier.
The first kind of case study here is using Ghostwriter. So we use this a bunch internally.
We use it mostly for Mythic Sync for in this specific case. So Mythic Sync is a script that
you can go ahead and set up with Mythic that goes through and registers Mythic's API to listen for
new taskings and automatically ingest it into the Oplog entry. So you inherently get free task
logging, which is fantastic. But there are other things that we want to do on top of this. As
you're operating, you are adding objectives or marking objectives as complete. You're tracking
new tasks or things as evidence for the stuff that you're doing. You're registering new findings,
all this sort of stuff that's outside of just simply tracking, hey, you know, I issued this
command at this UDC timestamp. So all this sort of stuff, because Ghostwriter has an API, we can
also leverage right from tasking. So as part of this, you'll need two things mainly. So you need
to, in Ghostwriter, create your user-specific API token. Okay. Easy enough. And then you need to tell
Mythic where Ghostwriter lives. Okay. That's, I mean, an easy ask. You should know where it lives
already. You're accessing it. So you can use these to then build your agent. So in this case, just like
we saw with Arachne, where you can make a fake callback, we're going to do the same thing and say,
hey, here's a fake callback from a Ghostwriter instance, which is never going to phone home to
you. It's its own separate third party platform. But now you can issue tasks and tell Ghostwriter
to do things for you. So just some examples of things that we have added into this Ghostwriter
agent. You can manipulate findings. You can add new findings. You can attach findings to reports. You
can change CVSS scores, all that sort of stuff. You can track new objectives, mark objectives as
complete, all of that. You can create new evidence, delete evidence, update evidence. We use the
Oplog already with like Mythic Sync. But you can search the Oplog. You can edit the Oplog entries.
You can do all that sort of stuff right in line. And of course, you can modify and manipulate your
reports. So what does this look like? Well, it should look like just any other tasking that you
do in an agent. And remember, because we are getting API-level access, we're hitting Ghostwriter's API,
but now we're getting UI control, we can do API-level things with more user-friendly interfaces.
So here, we're hitting Ghostwriter's API, getting back GraphQL data, and we can turn it into these
actionable tables. So you can see here all the findings that we have, their Ghostwriter-colored
specific severity levels, whether it's completed, who's reviewing it, all this sort of stuff. You can
just update it in real time as you're going along and operating. Same sort of stuff with objectives.
You can see what's going on, what objectives you still have left to complete, all of that. You can
go through and search your Oplog entries. You can edit them. You can see like, oh, you know, did this
thing happen? Or what kinds of things have we done on specific tools? All that sort of stuff readily
available. And of course, you can go through and manipulate the evidence. So this is one of the
things that's a bit tougher to do as you're operating. You do something, you issue a task, now you have a
finding, you need to go and make some sort of evidence for that finding of what you did, when you
did it, maybe a screenshot, like all that sort of stuff. You can start doing a lot more of that now
in this agent right from your normal platform. And of course, you can always go to Ghostwriter
directly and polish and edit and do a little kind of cleanup around the rough edges. But this
allows you to get a lot of that kind of inline reporting done for you without breaking your main
operational flow. The other big one I really want to talk about is Bloodhound. And I know a lot of
people here use Bloodhound. It's freaking awesome. There are just some added benefits that we can get
if we can talk to Bloodhound from within our C2 platform. So specifically with Bloodhound's
Community Edition. Super awesome. Helps you find a lot of these attack paths. Uses graph theory to find
shortest paths between nodes. It collects a lot of awesome data that you can represent. The nice
thing is it focuses on edges and paths that are, you know, actually abusable. Not just theory, but things
that you can actually do. Which is nice because from a C2 platform, we're interested in actually
doing things. We're trying to run things on agents. So this Community Edition specifically
has Docker, which I already like because Mythic uses Docker. And has its own Postgres database and
React Web UI. So that's fantastic. There are some pros and cons, though. So the Bloodhound CE UI
can display a lot of nodes, can display a lot of edges. It's easy to click around. You can see a
lot of the related metadata. All sorts of stuff along with it. Has a really nice, clean UI for how
you're going about doing things. The downside is that that's not a collaborative UI. If I'm clicking
around in a Bloodhound graph or searching things and I want to share that with a colleague, we need
to hop and share a screen so you can see what I'm clicking. I can't just, like, send you a link to
then see what it is that I'm seeing. You can't backtrack. So if you click down into certain data
and you want to go back to that original query that you used, you can't easily hop back and see
what was going on. So your kind of thought process along the way to finding maybe a vulnerable target
or an ideal attack path gets lost along the way. Once you get some data, it's not necessarily easy
to go through and prune it back to see, you know, maybe you had some Cypher query that pulled a lot
of data, but only part of it is what you're interested in to try and prune that down to
something that's a bit more manageable. You can't task agents through this. So this is a whole
separate UI. So if you find something that you want to target, you then have to, like, copy SIDs
and usernames and stuff and go into whatever platform you're using and paste it in there and do
all that. So that requires a lot of context switching. So with Bloodhound Community Edition,
though, there is now an API. I love this. This means that we can go through and hit this API
the same way that we're talking to Ghostwriter. So the nice thing, Bloodhound Community Edition
provides a easy Python example of how to go through and communicate and get API tokens and
all this sort of stuff. So you can get up and going pretty quickly. This is an example from their
internal API docs that allows you to search for the endpoints and the data and stuff that you get back.
So just like with the Bloodhound agent, all we really need to do is for your user, go through
and generate your API token. And whenever you create this kind of fake agent callback, you just
need to tell Mythic where Bloodhound lives. So that's all you really need to do. We can see here
we're building a payload type for Bloodhound. We just tell it where Bloodhound actually exists for
us. And now we can start doing a lot of awesome things. So we have access to Cypher queries.
You can access your saved Cypher queries, the predefined ones. You can get information about
objects. You can upload new JSON files to Bloodhound straight from Mythic. You can find
shortest path. You can find outbound controllable, like all sorts of stuff that is available in the
Bloodhound UI. They have exposed through API that we can then write commands to interact with.
So remember, Bloodhound works in graphs, though. A lot of what we've seen so far in the UI
controllability for Mythic is looking at tables. Well, why don't we just also add graphs to Mythic's
UI? So the new Mythic now has an option for you to take this structured data and not just return
tables for it, but return nodes, edges, properties, all sorts of stuff on these things that you can
then render in the UI. Now, remember, one of the things that I said that Bloodhound CE UI does
really well is it allows you to display and render a lot of nodes and edges pretty performantly.
Mythic is not Bloodhound UI. So Mythic goes ahead and says, if you try and render a graph that has
more than 50 nodes, it may work just fine, but it may slow things down. So it will automatically
collapse and hide those graphs for you to explicitly allow, like, okay, yeah, if this takes
five seconds to render because I got, you know, 350 nodes, I'm okay with that, and then it will
display it for you. But that's just kind of as you go through doing a lot of these queries, not
freezing your UI as you're trying to render this sort of stuff. So what does this look like?
Looks just like this. You can go ahead and see the various icons, and you can do overlay icons for,
like, the high-value targets or, you know, nodes that you've marked as owned, just like you expect
in Bloodhound. And you can see the paths for what's going on. So we can see here, like, local admin,
member of domain admins, all the sorts of data readily available for you. Down here on the side,
there are some helpful buttons for you to zoom in, zoom out. You can auto-size things to your view.
You can also, whatever you currently view, you can save as a screenshot. So whatever you finally
pruned things down to, you can just save that off and use it as evidence further on. And over here
is a little mini-map. So it shows all the nodes that are currently represented and how far in or
out you're zoomed. And so instead of trying to click around and scroll in the UI, you can just
use this little mini-map and drag this little center square here to change whatever it is that
you're trying to look at. Now, this is a really small graph, right? There's only a couple of nodes.
What if you have something a bit more complicated? So lots of things going on here. It's hard to kind
of figure out what it is I'm looking at. Or if there was one specific node I was interested in,
like, what can it do? Well, with Mythic, for these nodes, you can go ahead and select any individual
node. And you can hold shift and select multiple nodes and see just what they have inbound and
outbound control over. So that makes it a lot easier to kind of condense these more complicated
graphs into something that's easier to understand. On top of that, you can hide and have custom
actions for these nodes and edges. So we can select five nodes that we're interested in and say,
hide everything else. And all you'll see is those nodes and their paths. So it makes it a bit easier
to go through and kind of prune down a noisy query to what it is you're actually interested
in looking at. You can also go through and view all the additional data that comes back
as part of Bloodhound's API. You can mark certain nodes as owned or unmark them as owned, depending
on what it is that you're doing as part of your operations. Same with the shortest path and stuff
like that. So if you go through and you take a graph, you can then prune it. And now you can see
that same graph is much easier to see the specific path I'm interested in. And now I can take a
screenshot of just that path to then include as part of like a report or things like that. So it
makes stuff a little bit easier. But the nice thing about being able to have Bloodhound inside
of Mythic is that you can start leveraging Mythic agents to do things. So Mythic already provides a
way for you to go through and task agents via buttons in the UI. So instead of you on the
command line typing out a command, you can just click a button and Mythic will figure out
automatically what command it is you're trying to issue. So we can see these things down here
with file browser list. If you open up the file browser and you click the little
refresh list this folder icon or right click and task it, what Mythic does is it looks to see if
you have any command loaded in that callback that says that the command supports file browser list.
If it does, take those parameters, automatically issue that task for you. That's how Mythic is able
to do a lot of this UI task buttons because it's kind of this accepted way of messaging
between Mythic and these commands. So there are some that are always present in Mythic. Like if
you go into the callback list and say exit, it has to know what command to actually issue for you.
So all this stuff is automatically tracked. You as an agent developer can also say I support,
you know, Bloodhound member of or I support Ghostwriter ad report. Like you can define
whatever these things that you want are and you can use them in your own tasking. So what we can
do is as part of Bloodhound, we can say, you know what, for every edge I'm going to go ahead and define
a new UI feature where I'll return whatever is meaningful for the edge. So maybe for some edges
you give the source and destination. For maybe others you give source destination and service
principal name. Like all sorts of stuff that you can define and then other agents can say, hey, I
support that. If somebody does that, tell me. I got you hooked up. I will execute a command for you.
So looking here specifically, we can say the two highlighted pieces here, what UI feature, in this
case Bloodhound something, and then the nice thing down there is select callback true. Normally Mythic
looks in the same callback that you're executing to see what kind of commands you want to do as
follow on. That doesn't make sense for Bloodhound because we're not trying to task Bloodhound to
run commands for us. So you say select callback and we'll automatically get a pop-up that says
what callback do you want to task. Here's another example down here where we, as part of this graph
view rendering, we say, oh, hey, this node that we got back has service principal names. I'm going to
go ahead and loop through them and for each one I'm going to add a button that says curb roast
this service principal name. So you can just right-click a node and say curb roast and do the
thing for you. And you can see that manifesting down here. We had these already by default and
now we added, hey, do this curb roast. So this is a quick little video going through showing that we
are in an Apollo callback that has some commands loaded in for us. We're going to go to our
Bloodhound callback, look at this node. We'll go ahead and turn off the browser script so it doesn't
render the graph but you can see the raw data that Bloodhound's API returns. And you can see as part
of these properties has SPN and we have a list of service principles. Sweet. So as part of our
rendering for this graph, we have decided that we'll go ahead and add a context menu option for you
to say curb roast. So that goes through and if we have in another callback a supported UI feature,
in this case Bloodhound colon curb roast, then we'll go ahead and execute that command for the
callback that we specified with the parameters that we identified. So it goes over here and for
that Apollo callback automatically issues this execute cough command to then pass in these
parameters and do everything there. So we're able to go through, and this is a test domain so it
doesn't actually have that service principle in it, but what we're able to do here is automatically
task other callbacks directly based on the data that we're getting back from Bloodhound. So it
shortens that loop for you that makes things a bit easier.

you have a basic auth, username and password. So that's the stuff that you would set up as part of

and processing master keys and decrypting Chrome data, we can just issue Chromium and say, hey, you

click a password and use it. Or you can just click around the various data that's getting returned.

Nemesis, you can do it right here in the UI as well. Provide a file, upload it, get it ingested and
start having it processed on the back end. Going forward, Nemesis is going to expand and provide

querying Nemesis for data, let's start pushing data. If we got maybe passwords from screenshots
or key logging or stuff like that that's not in a file or something that's automatically processed
by Nemesis, let's tell Nemesis about it and then have Nemesis kick off that processing. So we can
do a lot of stuff with this as Nemesis API starts expanding and getting more and more stuff in there.
So to kind of wrap up these third-party accesses, you get per user access to whatever it is
that you're trying to do. You get graph or like API level access to whatever it is that you're

You get automatic tracking, you get collaboration, you get all this sort of stuff that now everybody

So when you're developing features, how do you balance third-party integrations and the amount
of work you're duplicating? So you reinvented a lot of the Bloodhound UI. How do you
judge that level of workload versus just pitching off and say use the Bloodhound UI instead?
Yeah that's a great question. So I try and look at it if there's additional context I can get
as part of re-implementing or re-adding that. So Mythic already uses a graph library for viewing
callbacks. So adding in a graphing library wasn't something new. All I did was just create like a
React node that says like here's how you render this thing. But the benefit I get from that is
more agents can now use that. So if you have other data that makes sense to represent in a graph,
you can use that without having to figure out how to add that into like Bloodhound's UI.
And we get additional features from it. So like the ability here to be able to just right click
a node and say task my already existing Apollo agent to do this thing. I think that is a high
enough bar of like user feasibility and like effectiveness that it's worth doing. If it was just
like displaying the UI, maybe not as much. But yeah. So I guess the follow-up question is so what
made you choose to put that in the Mythic rather than just adding the integration in Bloodhound's
existing UI? So you have Bloodhound up and you have that edge connection but instead Bloodhound
tasks Mythic rather than Mythic tasking itself. I think it's easier to have the agent identify
everything that it needs outside of needing Bloodhound to know about how Apollo does something
versus Merlin does something versus something else. It's easier to keep as much of that as
possible within the agent developer's realm. And so it's easier for them to create their own agent
and do things that way than trying to get maybe something else that they want to add it in.
Getting Rohan and the Bloodhound team to get that added into their roadmap over
